response.answer_text: Yes, they are! Many are scams because the companies are very bad and/or the contracts are written in a manner to limit payouts. Just GOOGLE US Fidelis for an example of how many of these companies operate. This is particularly true with third party (not from the manufacturer) extended service contracts related to vehicles. These are the companies who send you bizarre letters or emails or flood the TV with ads prommising things any reasonably intelligent person should realize are impossible. All are scams due to the manner in which they are priced. First, the providers of the contract use experts to determine the expected payout. Second, the contract is sold to the dealer at a profit. Third the dealer sells the contract to the buyer, again at a profit. In the end you have a contract with two levels of profit over the expected payout. These contracts are huge profit makers for the dealer which, of course, is why they push them so hard. All most all independent consumer advocates advice against extended service contracts. For these reasons. Obviously, a contract costing $100 for an electronic product is a much less risky purchase than a contract related to a new vehicle which may cost $2,000 or so. If you do buy one of these contracts, make sure you fully understand the small print and fully understand the cost relationship of the contract to the replacement cost of the product including the likelihood of actually using the contract.

Considering the current scenario, they are a must thing to buy with the product. Device components like display, battery etc. are becoming more and more advanced and as a result repair costs have escalated. So, if in case you are getting extended warranties or protection programs like CMP by Flipkart and Acko by Amazon are the best insurance you can have for your device. Nowadays, one of the main USP’s of devices like laptops and smartphones are their displays which is the weakest part of the device. So, there are more chances of you accidentally breaking it a span of 2 or 3 years life of the product. Moreover, display repairs usually cost around 1/3rd of the actual cost of the product. In these case Protection programs and extended warranties really help you mitigate the cost and save you money in the long term. Also, these extended warranties and Protection Programs are usually on offer if you buy them with the product. So, paying a little extra during the purchase can save you a lot in the near future. If a laptop has accidental warranty go for it. Similarly for every device these warranties are beneficial in the long term. There are very few people who can actually use a device unscathed for more than 2 or 3 years. Something or the other is bound to happen. As they say “Prevention is always better than cure”

I have purchased several extended warranties with Honda. They have never turned down a claim. I will add that there were not many issues over the term. When a issue came up the dealer I visited treated it like I was a customer with a problem, write up a service request and inform me the initial cost will be one hour diagnostic charge. When the problem was found to be under warranty it was repaired for free and the diagnostic fee dropped. I would suggest not buying a third party warranty, they seem to be the one`s that want to fight claims. I have heard of stories were when an internal engine problem claim was submitted the cars owner was told to “have the engine opened up” at their cost and the warranty company would send out a rep to investigate and see if it was a covered issue. So, again, I would stay with the car Manufacturer`s Warranty…

response.answer_text: Each state has a department that oversees car dealers, and one for insurance. If you did not buy the extended warranty from a dealer, choose the insurance or consumer affairs departments to register a complaint. You can also cancel an extended warranty at any time and receive a prorated refund. If the refund does not reach you within 30 days, call the departments as above.
